_prev_prog_3.Description: The crude tower Naphtha Overhead process, consisting of Naphtha, includes approximately 18,000 lbs of inventory, and includes the crude tower overhead, a naphtha accumulator, a series of heat exchangers, and associated pumps and piping. Two 20,000 gallon Atmospheric Naphtha Storage Tanks, which include an administrative control limiting the inventory to 22 of the 24 feet height of the tanks (approximately 91.7%). Combining the Naphtha Process and the two Storage Tanks, results in a total maximum inventory of 256,420 lbs of naphtha.  The naphtha flammable mixture contains the following covered flammable chemicals; 2.41% butane, 2.52% isopentane, 2.70% pentane.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
World Oil Refining is a 9500bpd crude oil processing facility that produces finished asphalt and unfinished petroleum distillates. The facility encompasses roughly 5 acres of land in South Gate, California. There are operations that occupy space on both east (9302) and west (9301) sides of Garfield Avenue.

The facility has developed a risk management program to address the EPA RMP requirements (40 CFR Part 68) and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (19 CCR Division 2, Chapter 4.5).  World Oil Refining is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The World Oil Refining staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely distilling and storing the covered chemical, naphtha.

 

1.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

World Oil Refining has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the covered processes.  World Oil Refining's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.

 

2.0 STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The main operation at World Oil Refining is crude oil distillation. The facility uses atmospheric distillation and vacuum distillation as the means to physically separate the crude oil into fractions. There are no chemical or catalytic reactions that take place within the process. Distillate products consist of full-range naphtha, diesel (sold as Light Distillate Oil or LDO), light vacuum gas oil (sold as LVGO) and heavy vacuum gas oil (combined with LVGO or sold as Cutter Stock for the bunker fuel market). The distillate products are loaded at the Distillate Loading Rack on the east side of Garfield Avenue. Vapors emitted

during loading are routed to an incinerator (I-501). 



On the refinery site, there are some utility operations that support the Crude Unit. These include a SulfaTreat Unit used to strip H2S from the gases coming off the Crude Unit, a Waste Water Treatment Plant that treats water generated from the process and routes it to the L.A. County Sanitation sewer system, a boiler that provides 200 psig steam for the plant and an incinerator (I-301) that is utilized to destroy off-gases from the SulfaTreat Unit, vapors from asphalt truck loading, vapors from the tank vent vapor recovery system and vapors from the Waste Water Treatment Plant. An oxidized roofing production plant or Air Blown Plant (AB Plant) is located within the refinery perimeter and consists of four separate vessels called stills, four seal pots (one for each still), mechanical blowers that deliver air to the process stills, and a caustic scrubbing unit to clean the off-gas from the AB Plant before it is sent to the incinerator (I-301). The roofing asphalt produced is shipped via pipeline and via truck.



The covered processing areas were determined to be as follows:

-Crude & Vacuum Unit

-Cooling Water System

-Sulfur Removal & Treatment

-Utilities

-Air Blow Plant & Incinerator

-Tank Farm & Loading/Unloading Racks



World Oil Refining processes crude oil and hence handles all the hydrocarbons that comprise crude oil.  Thus, there are hazardous substances that are utilized in or generated by the process.  Based on the EPA definitions of flammable hydrocarbons, the quantities of the regulated flammable mixture in processing areas as well as at storage tanks at the facility should be determined. For the purpose of determining the worst-case release scenario, the largest quantity in the World Oil Refining facility was determined to be Naphtha with a TOTAL of 256,420 lbs. of Naphtha.  



The facility has designated two Covered Processes associated with Naphtha which are included in the Naphtha Process

& Storage.  These are as follows:

-Crude & Vacuum Unit

The crude tower Naphtha Overhead process, consisting of Naphtha, includes approximately 18,000 lbs. of inventory, and includes the crude tower overhead, a naphtha accumulator, a series of heat exchangers, and associated pumps and piping.

-Tank Farm & Loading/Unloading Racks

Two atmospheric Naphtha storage tanks, each with a 20,000-gallon capacity, include an administrative control limiting the maximum inventory to 22 of the 24 ft. height of the tanks (approximately 91.7%), which provide the ability to store a maximum of 119,210 lbs. of Naphtha in each tank, for a total maximum inventory of 238,420 lbs. of Naphtha.

 

3.0 HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary for Toxics

Not Applicable for CalARP Program and EPA RMP.

 

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary for Toxics

Not Applicable for CalARP Program and EPA RMP.

 

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary for Flammables

Scenario Description: The worst-case release scenario for Naphtha assumes a release of the entire contents of the largest container (1 Storage Tank: 119,210 pounds). Using the parameters mandated by regulations through the RMP*Comp program, this worst-case release has the potential to traverse a 0.4-mile radius from the point of release and the potential to affect a population of 933 people.

 

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary for Flammables

Scenario Description: The alternative release scenario selected for Naphtha is the scenario that is most likely to occur than the worst-case scenario. This scenario was determined to be the pool fire scenario. Using the parameters mandated by regulations through RMP*Comp program, this alternative release has the potential to traverse a 0.3-mile radius from the point of release and the potential to affect a population of 145 people.

 

Risk Considerations

Although petroleum refining has inherent potential risks,

and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; World Oil Refining has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the use of conservative analysis, assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a flammable hydrocarbon release:

-The system has alarms and automatic shut-offs and controls to minimize the potential for operating outside the normal parameters.

-The system undergoes periodic preventive maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

 

4.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this Risk Management Program, key Prevention Program elements were implemented by World Oil Refining to manage process safety issues associated with the covered processes. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

World Oil Refining 's EPA RMP Prevention Program 3 and CalARP Prevention Program 4 elements for the flammable substance, Naphtha, include: 

Common Elements of EPA RMP Prevention Program 3 and CalARP Prevention Program 4

-Process Safety Information

-Process Hazard Analysis

-Operating Procedures

-Training

-Mechanical Integrity

-Management of Change

-Pre-Startup Safety Review

-Compliance Audits

-Incident Investigation

-Employee Participation

-Hot Work Permits

-Contractors

-Emergency Planning & Response

 

In addition to the CalARP program 4 elements mentioned above, World Oil Refining has included the following CalARP program 4 elements as part of its prevention program:

-Management of Organizational Change

-Safeguard Protection Analysis

-Damage Mechanism Review 

-Hierarchy of Hazard Control Analysis

-Process Safety Culture Assessment

-Human Fa

ctors Program

 

5.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Prior to the delivery date of this document, there have been no EPA RMP-related and CalARP Program-related accidents at the World Oil Refining in the past five (5) years.  An incident investigation procedure is kept onsite which summarizes the required data to be reported in the RMP* submit printout, and will be utilized, as necessary to document any EPA RMP and CalARP Program-related incidents.

 

6.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

World Oil Refining is committed to providing a safe and healthful work environment for its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment. The prevention of accidents, injuries, fires, emergency releases and other emergency situations is of utmost importance and shall be the first priority for all persons working at the refinery.

 

World Oil Refining is not a first responder. Thus, World Oil Refining has an Emergency Action Plan in place and submits appropriate documentation regarding the chemicals and associated quantities to be included in the community emergency response plan.

 

7.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The planned changes to improve safety at the facility resolve the recommendations derived from the Process Hazard Analysis, as well as incorporated recommendations from compliance audits and incident investigations, as they become available.  The facility has a tracking system for implementing these recommendations and ensuring its closure.  As required by the regulations, recommendations will be addressed and closed in a timely manner.
